_header: O ye that put your trust and confidence
_description:
‘The lamentacioun off quene Elyȝabeth’, A.D. 1503, ascribed to Thomas More — twelve stanzas rhyme royal, with Latin lines and refrain, ‘…lo here I lye’. Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler TM 1257.

OxfBal354.First Lines:
Ye þat put your trust & confydenceIn worldly riches &
                    frayll prosperyte…
OxfBal354.Last Lines:
…I me commend to thy Infenyte mercyShew to thi seruaunt now
                    for lo here I lye
OxfBal354.Facsimiles:
Early Manuscripts at Oxford University: Facsimile
                    of Oxford, Balliol MS 354.
         (http://image.ox.ac.uk/show?collection=balliol&manuscript=ms354).
OxfBal354.Editions:
Flügel,  Ewald. 
             “Liedersammlungen des XVI Jahrhunderts….” 
             Anglia
         26 (1903): 94-285: 184-8.
Dyboski,  R.,
                        ed.  
             Songs, Carols and Other Miscellaneous Poems from Balliol MS. 354,
                Richard Hill’s Commonplace Book.
EETS
          e.s. 101 (1908); repr. 1984: 97-9.

BLSl1825.First Lines:
O you that putt youre trust and convidenceIn worldely Ioye and
                    ffrayle Prosperytethat leve here as you shuld never henceRemember deth
                    and loke vp here to me…
BLSl1825.Last Lines:
…I me commend to thy Infenyte mercyeshewe to thy seruaunt for
                    lo nowe here I lye
BLSl1825.Note:
Added to blank leaves at end of volume by a hand of the sixteenth
                    century; first word (in a few cases first two words) of each stanza written in
                    larger script in left margin beside first line of each.
BLSl1825.Attributed Title:
O You that putt youre trust & convydence (f. 88v, written by
                    scribe immediately above first line in slightly larger script)
